Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Coupled Flow-Chemistry Modeling of Thrombogensis in Human Ventricles

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1511200(Mittal)

The proposal is focused on the understanding of the flow of blood in the human heart using computations. When blood flow in the heart is disturbed by myocardial infraction, it is possible to create conditions that lead to blood clotting. The novelty of the proposed work is in the use of computational models that account not only for the flow, but also for the detailed biochemistry of clot formation. Hundreds of thousands of Americans each year are found to suffer from myocardial infraction and could potentially benefit from the results of this research.

Despite many decades of research, the complex interplay between the ventricular fluid dynamics and the chemistry of coagulation is not well understood. It is proposed to take advantage of recent developments in medical imaging and computational fluid dynamics to simulate blood flow in realistic models of the heart, and to investigate the coupling between the flow and the chemistry associated with left ventricle (LV) thrombogenesis. It is proposed to use medical imaging to create a model of the LV to simulate blood flow. The resulting flow field data will be used to model the convection, diffusion and reaction of species known to be important in the coagulation cascade as well as platelet dynamics and adhesion. The specific objectives of the project are: (1) develop coupled flow-chemistry computational models of LV thrombus formation; (2) validate computational hemodynamic results against in-vivo data; (3) investigate the mechanisms of flow-mediated thrombogenesis; and (4) use simulations to examine alternate coagulation pathways and the effectiveness of anticoagulant therapies. This project will break new ground in flow-chemistry coupling, imaging-to-model construction, hybrid (CPU-GPU) high performance computing models, dual-time-stepping procedures for stiff coupled systems, and new protocols for validating CFD results from in-vivo data. The coupled flow-chemical modeling approach that will be developed is expected to advance the state-of-the-art in this arena that has been limited to simple, stationary vessel geometries and laminar flows.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Stroke is one of the leading causes of death and the most common cause of neurological disability in the U.S. One mechanism for cardioembolic stroke is via thrombi that develop in the left-ventricle (LV) of patients with myocardial infarction. In recent years, the prevalence of thrombosis in implanted transcatheter aortic valves (TAV) has also emerged as an important risk-factor for stroke in patients with valvular disease. The research conducted in this project has developed computational tools as well as fundamental insights that address both these conditions. The key technical outcomes of the project are (a) development of efficient and highly scalable coupled chemo-fluidic models of thrombogenesis that include time-accurate modeling of transitional/turbulent flows and multi-step reaction kinetics for coagulation in the presence of moving boundaries; (b) development of a new metric that that predicts the risk of LV thrombosis from echocardiographic scans of heart patients; and (c) new insights into reduced-leaflet motion of TAVs with early leaflet thrombosis.

The impact of the current project has extended beyond cardiac fluid mechanics into the broader areas of computational biophysics and biomechanics, since many of the ideas in modeling, simulation, computation and analysis developed here have direct application to other organ systems (e.g. respiratory, phonatory, vascular), to reactive (combustion), environmental (pollutant and effluent transport) and ecological (algal transport) flows, as well as to the broad disciplines of fluid mechanics, biology and high-performance computing. Training of undergraduates and graduate students has contributed to a new generation of scientists and engineers who can apply computational science and mechanics across cross-disciplinary boundaries. Educational impact has been multiplied by translating the research into lecture modules for undergraduate and graduate level courses. Data from the project has been made available to the broader community via published papers, proceedings, conference presentations and seminars. Information from this research has also been disseminated to the public via news articles and media coverage.


Last Modified: 07/23/2020
Modified by: Rajat Mittal

    Image from patient-specific simulation of left-ventricular thrombosis.
  • : (a) Proposed sensor system for early detection of leaflet dysfunction in (a) longitudinal and (b) axial views. The system uses two sensors per leaflet, which are aligned along the centerline of each leaflet. Each sensor pair includes one sensor placed in the aortic sinus and the other near the sin
    Shantanu Bailoor, Jung-Hee Seo, Rajat mittal
    Creative Commons
    Rajat Mittal
    Proposed Sensorized Transcather Valve System for Detecting Early Leaflet Thrombosis
  • a) Segmented patient-specific aorta model and differences in flow features in this aorta morphology using (b) a healthy, tricuspid valve and (b) a left-right fused bicuspid valve, indicating the presence of a stronger aortic jet and flow swirl, characteristic of a fused bicuspid valve.
    Shantanu Bailoor, Jung-Hee Seo, Stefano Schena, Stefan Zimmerman,Rajat mittal
    Creative Commons
    Rajat Mittal
    Simulation of Flow in a Patient Aorta with a normal and biscuspid valve.

Training of undergraduates and graduate students has contributed to a new generation of scientists and engineers who can apply computational science and mechanics across cross-disciplinary boundaries. Educational impact has been multiplied by translating the research into lecture modules for undergraduate and graduate level courses. Data from the project has been made available to the broader community via published papers, proceedings, conference presentations and seminars.
